subject: Photography
title: The Eye vs. the Camera
description: A short lesson to help you apply The Eye vs. the Camera.

hook.text: Your eye adjusts for brightness, color, and focus instantly. A camera records one moment, one setting, one truth.

buildup.text: Human vision is dynamic â€” constantly scanning, adapting, and interpreting. A camera captures a frozen instant.

discovery.text: The eye has a wider dynamic range but a narrow point of focus. Cameras capture everything in the frame equally.

twist.text: A photo never looks like what you saw because you didn't 'see' a single frame. Your brain assembled a composite.

climax.text: Learning photography means learning the gap between vision and capture â€” and using that gap creatively.

punchline.text: Your eye sees a scene. Your camera sees a photograph. Learn the difference.

quiz.question: Why does a photograph often look different from what you saw?
options: Your brain assembles a composite but the camera captures a single frozen instant
The human eye is less accurate than a camera
